headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Former GA Gov. Roy Barnes Testifies At Fani Willis Hearing; Fani Willis' Father Testifies At Disqualification Hearing. Aired 11- 11:30a ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ultimately, you turned down.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, I told her, I said, I'm not interested. Nothing further from the state, your honor.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE SCOTT MCAFEE, FULTON COUNTY SUPERIOR COURT
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant?

utterances.speaker: ASHLEIGH MERCHANT, DEFENSE ATTORNEY FOR MIKE ROMAN
utterances.sentences: Thanks, your honor. Good morning, Governor Barnes. How are you?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant, good morning. Just fine. How are you?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Good. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You said it was sometime in 2021, do you remember if it was early?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I think it was. I don't remember the date. They all go. I could look it up on my calendar at the office, but I don't have that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Well, I want to ask you about some statements that Ms. Willis made, March 28th, 2021. She was talking about assembling a team for this case. Are you familiar with her work assembling a team for this case?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Well, I assume that's what she was talking to me about, but besides that, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I know you said you had a meeting with some folks, and Mr. Wade was at that meeting?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So he was with the district attorney interviewing you about taking this case.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Well, he, of course. I know Nathan very well, as you do.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: And I exchanged pleasantries with him. But the conversation was with Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK, with Ms. Willis. Were you aware at the time that her team consisted of Brian Watkins, Megan Vargas, Sonya Allen, Shannon Trotty, Sau Chan, and John Floyd? She had reported that was her team on this case.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I know John Floyd was involved, and she probably told me the others. But listen, I barely remember what case I tried last year, much less every word that was said in the conversation.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I understand. Fair enough. But she said she was looking to hire more lawyers and investigators to work on this case?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: She told me, it was to me. She said, would you be interested in being special prosecutor in this case? And I gave the reply that I've already known. I mean, about hiring other lawyers or whatever, I don't know. All I can testify to is what she told me.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did she tell you at all why she wanted to hire special counsel and not use someone who was an ADA, not have an actual employee?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No, she did not. I mean, we did not discuss that. But I would assume it was cause in a case as big as this that you'd have to have a decision. I know John Floyd has been in some cases over the years, out in Cobb County, for example, and others.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Would you agree that an employee of her office, someone who was paid a state salary or a county salary as an ADA, could handle a case like this?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I couldn't tell you that unless I knew the person, knew their experience, and really had been with them in a courtroom base an opinion on that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sadow?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Hello, Mr. Sadow.STEVE SADOW, DONALD TRUMP'S DEFENSE ATTORNEY: It has been a while.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: It has been a while.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I hope you're well.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I'm doing fine. Just getting older with that beats off.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's true. But that applies to all of us, I believe.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I think you indicated that if you had your calendar, you'd be able to pinpoint a date for us?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I would.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Is there a way for you, for example, at a break before you actually leave to contact your folks to see if you can get a date?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I guess I could. I don't know how far back we archive those, but I assume I could.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Would you be willing to give that a shot for us.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I mean, I'll do whatever the court instructs.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So if I ask the court and the court says, go ahead, and you could do it, that's all right?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I'll do whatever the court instructs.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I hear you.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: And you should, too.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I try to live by those words. I'm not always successful, but I try. If I pinpoint a date, for example, I think the record is clear that Mr. Wade was hired for the position on November 1, 2021. Does that help you at all?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No. It does not.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. Then let's go to the meeting. It sounds like it was just one meeting?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And could you tell us where that meeting took place, if you remember?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: It was in the conference room adjacent to the district attorney's office.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So was it in this adjoining building?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: It was in Lewis Slaton Building.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And District Attorney Willis was there, obviously, right?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And Mr. Wade was there, the best I recall. BARNES

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Do you have a recollection of anyone else being present?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Do you remember. Were you introduced to Mr. Wade by anything other than you already knew him? Was he given a title or anything?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No. I would have known.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So, at least as you're there, if I heard you correctly, Ms. Willis did all the talking and Mr. Wade did not?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I mean, we exchanged pleasantries, but as far as the basis of the conversation, the reason I was there, Ms. Willis did the talk.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And would you be able to give us an estimate how long this meeting lasted? Just rough.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Probably an hour.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. And during the meeting, you made it clear, but it was the thanks for the offer, but no, thank you?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, I did. As I said, you know, I started off as a prosecutor. And for about ten or 15 years, I did nothing but criminal. And then but I've tried to move away from it and do primarily civil now. Mr. Gillen and I have done some white collar cases over in federal court. I've got one over there right now, but it's generally business related, you know, where I have a client that's got a kid or him getting indicted. And the case I have over there now is an alleged fraud case.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Fair to say that based on your career and the work that you've done, you've handled high profile cases, correct?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I have. I've handled some pretty good cases. I sued Syria one time for beheading a client of mine, recovered $80 million. I guess that's the best high profile. But that was in D.C. I tried that up in D.C.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And what would be considered complex cases, you've handled those as well, correct?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean we regularly do mass torts, class actions, business torts, breach of contract, and most of those are high complex, our complex requiring many experts. I also -- we also do malpractice. I did malpractice defense for about 25 years. But since I've returned from the governor's office, I try not to represent an insurance company anymore. And I just tried a malpractice case before Judge Edlin in November. And those are complex cases because of the type know medical knowledge that you have to have, and also because of the many experts that you have.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did Ms. Willis, and this is the last question, did Ms. Willis tell you why she had sought you, why you had been her choice?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No, I hadn't. But I get consulted fairly often on major cases.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Would you believe based on circumstances in which you were given the offer, that it had to do with fact, that you had handled complex and high profile cases in the past?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: It could have been. I know her very well. The -- I tried a case against her. She worked for the JQC. And I represented Judge Robert Crawford, Mack Crawford. And she prosecuted him, and I defended him. She beat me at the trial. I turned it around at the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So you had some experience with her?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Oh, I had plenty of experience with her. She's a very qualified young, well, everybody is young to me, but she's a very qualified young woman.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: After that one occasion, did you have any other contact with her in reference to the position itself or who she might be considering?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: You know, I had some conversations with her or Jeff DeSantis or some of those, but not really an in depth, you know, about who she should hire or anything like that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did the name Nathan Wade come up in those conversations with her?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No, no.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No. Right?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No. Nathan was there I thought and I could be mistaken, but I thought Nathan was there when I was -- I thought Nathan was -- I'm positive Nathan was there when I met with them.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I don't think so. I don't recall one. I mean, Nathan is a good organizer. You know, Nathan can organize stuff. I've watched him over the years, so I wasn't surprised that he was acting as a special prosecutor.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And Mr. DeSantis, for the record, who was Jeff DeSantis?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Jeff, Jeff DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Do you know who he is?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Could you tell us who he is for the record?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Jeff works in the DA's office. I knew him when he worked for Thurbert Baker.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Do you know what his role in the DA's office is?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I have no earthly idea.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Is he in media, does that sound familiar?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: He has done media in the past. Jeff has generally been, I like Jeff and I'm very close to him. But he's generally been on the other side of my campaign.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All right, so we're talking the best of your recollection conference. We don't have the date. I'm asking if you could possibly get it. But the conference you have, Mr. Wade could have been there?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm almost sure he was there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And Ms. Willis, obviously. And Mr. DeSantis was there?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I think Mr. DeSantis was too.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And as far as whether there was anyone else there, you don't have a present recollection?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No. Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: OK, thank you.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Next time I'll take a picture. So I'll have an exact.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Next time hopefully you won't have to be here.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Well, hopefully not.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, sir.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, Mr. Stockton (ph)?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No questions, your honor.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Durham? UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. McDougall?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No questions for the governor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Rice?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No questions, your honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Gillen?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I've been waiting for this.CRAIG GILLEN, DAVID SHAFER'S DEFENSE ATTORNEY: I couldn't give up the chance getting up here, Governor. Good to see you again.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Good to see you, Craig.

utterances.speaker: GILLEN
utterances.sentences: We've done some work in the past together, haven't we?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I consider you to be one of my best friends and a Cracker Jack lawyer.

utterances.speaker: GILLEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I will say to you on the record that I can understand why they came to see you, because you're the finest lawyer that I've ever worked with.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I need to put you in the next day.

utterances.speaker: GILLEN
utterances.sentences: Yes, there you go. We'll get that. But that, one or two more questions.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GILLEN
utterances.sentences: You and I working together when it's appropriate. There's, you know, we've had no qualms about filing motions to disqualify the DA, have we?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GILLEN
utterances.sentences: Matter of fact, you and I successfully disqualified the DA out in Cobb County in the Brown case, didn't we?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: We did.

utterances.speaker: GILLEN
utterances.sentences: So whatever needs to be done, should be done.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: Represent your client.

utterances.speaker: GILLEN
utterances.sentences: You got that, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Katoro (ph), are you still with us by Zoom?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I am, your honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, any questions?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No, sir.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, and Mr. Cromwell for Ms. Latham?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No questions, your honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, any redirect, Mr. Abbate? Can this witness be excused?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, your honor.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Your honor, is there a way that we could potentially ask through you for that date?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: The question is, you want the exact date that the meeting occurred?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. If you can give that to us.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: And I'm wondering if we can -- if it's really material, the exact date, rather than just its proximity to the November 1st hiring. Is that fair? If he knows whether it was far earlier in the year versus maybe closer, would that obviate the need for the exact date?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: If you can't get the exact date, unfortunately, take the best we can.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK, let's start there.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: All right, let me -- well --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: You may take care of it for us just what we hold in place here.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure for this.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Let me try this first, Governor Barnes, before you do a deep dive in the e-mail there. Do you recall what time of year it was when this meeting occurred?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I'm afraid not.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I mean, you know how this is. The cases and the days moved together. I had a fellow a few years ago that said I represent him in 1978, and I told him I'd take his word for it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I got to ask, you wouldn't do that if it was a question of him saying he just paid you?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: No, I would not. I will tell you, I believe lawyers should be well paid, Mr. Settler (ph).

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, so, sir, is that something you -- BARNES

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK. All right, we'll ask this witness to step down, subject to recall. And that might be something the state can present with stipulation as well. All right, thank you, sir. Do we have an update on Mr. Bradley?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: His lawyer should be here. He's probably outside.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: The last estimation I heard was about 11

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK. If that's still the case, then Ms. Cross, did you have another witness available?ANNA GREEN CROSS, ATTORNEY FOR FULTON COUNTY DA'S OFFICE: Having brought over, it's Mr. John Floyd, not the special prosecutor, John Floyd, District Attorney Willis's father.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: All right, I believe they have just called to the stand John Floyd, who was the father of Fani Willis. So that will be interesting testimony to hear any moment now. While we're waiting for him to take the stand, what we just did witness was, I think, the very small world of the Georgia legal profession right there. The former governor of Georgia, Roy Barnes, testified that he was offered at one point the job of being special prosecutor in the election fraud case against Donald Trump and others, and also testified a little bit to the qualifications of Nathan Wade, who ultimately did lead up that investigation. Michael Moore, you are part of this small world there. What did you hear what was most important?

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL MOORE, CNN LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Well, it was good to see Governor Barnes. He's a great guy and a friend and a great lawyer. But to me, the contrast then is very stark between the kind of lawyer that she talked about having as a special counsel and somebody who's never prosecuted a felony case and ends up being lead counsel in this case. And so I think the contrast that she's drawn may come back to bite her. And I don't think there's anybody in the courtroom that thinks that would have been an equal pairing. And she's just moving down the line.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That came after, though, and he was called as a witness for DA Fani Willis. Why would they want to make clear that someone was offered this job before Nathan Wade ultimately got it?

utterances.speaker: KAREN FRIEDMAN AGNIFILO, CNN LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: I think because they're really concerned about the fact that they're being accused of this disqualification, this conflict of interest, that the only reason Nathan Wade was hired, so that she could somehow financially benefit from monies that he was making by prosecuting this case. And if she can show that others were offered the job, they turned her down. You heard the former governor say that Wade is a good organizer. I'm not surprised that they brought him on for this case.It's showing kind of why he was hired. It wasn't that he was her boyfriend and she somehow wanted to financially benefit, it was more he's a good lawyer, and the other really good lawyers apparently turned her down.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: So, Elie, to that point, Michael Moore there just suggested what the defense lawyers tried to do is paint a contrast between the former governor and Nathan Wade, who was ultimately hired. But Governor Barnes testified that Wade does things well.

utterances.speaker: ELIE HONIG, CNN SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Yes. So there was something for both sides in what we just saw. So it is a key issue in this hearing here whether Nathan Wade was properly qualified to have this job. What Fani Willis did is she passed over her entire office of experienced prosecutors, people have been practicing in Fulton County, in Atlanta. I'll wait for the judge here.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Updates on Mr. Bradley?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. So he is still in this appointment (inaudible). However, he's going to make himself available via Zoom if that's possible? (Inaudible) to provide his testimony.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, Ms. Merchant?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: All right. I think what they're saying is that Mr. Bradley, Terrence Bradley, who is the witness they all really want to see, they're still waiting on him, but they still have called John Floyd, the father of Fani Willis, to the stand. We will wait for him to come in. Finish what you're saying Elie.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes. So theory of the defendants is that Fani Willis hired Nathan Wade for this job because he was her boyfriend, essentially. And what the DA's office was trying to establish right there is that actually she offered the job to somebody else first, this former governor. The problem, though, for the DA's office is the first thing out of the governor's mouth is when I went to this first meeting with Fani Willis, Nathan Wade was already there. So that doesn't really make the point they were hoping that they made that somehow Nathan Wade was not the first choice. He's already in the mix.But on the other hand, I think there was, depending how you look at it, a contrast between the credentials of Nathan Wade, who's been a lawyer for a long time but never prosecuted a felony, versus this governor who's done all sorts of big cases, so.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Let's listen back to Judge Scott McAfee down there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- all day. This appointment started at 9

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: I'm just trying to get more. I mean, we initially been told maybe it was going to be 9

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If it's, your honor, which he tells me come on in (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Is he, you know, without getting too much into the particulars, has he already been seen by the doctor and he's waiting for results, or is he still waiting to be seen by a doctor? I'm just, you know --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, he's been consulting with the doctor (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: After the, you know, able to figure out (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK. If you can get any kind of an update on how much time they think that those results they're going to take. If it's more than an hour or two, I think we would want to start bringing him here, and he can have that follow up consultation later. All right, thank you, sir.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) motion.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: At this point, I think we've got something else that can occupy our time, and I think we need to move forward with that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Understood.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Of course, yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I didn't learn about the equipment.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Right. OK, understood. Ms. Cross?

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: Yes, your honor. Mr. Abbate, will --ADAM ABBATE, ATTORNEY FOR FULTON COUNTY DA'S OFFICE: The states call Mr. John Floyd.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Floyd, if you could have a seat, sir.

utterances.speaker: CROSS
utterances.sentences: May I approach the witness quickly just --JOHN FLOYD, FANI WILLIS' FATHER: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Please be seated.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: This is John Floyd, the father of Fani Willis, testifying. Let's listen.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Good morning, sir.

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Can you tell the court, are you currently retired?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I am.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And prior to being retired, can you tell the court a little bit about, did you work in the legal career?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: I'm -- I was attorney. I practiced law. I've probably tried 1,000 cases. About 50 percent of my practice was criminal law, 25 percent of it was family law, and the rest was whatever walked through the front door could pay for it.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK. And --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Could we wait one second, please. Governor has come back. He might have to --

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.sentences: I do. My calendar shows it was October 26th, 2021.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right, and would defense counsel accept it as a stipulation, or is there any follow up questioning needed on that? Mr. Barnes is still considered under oath on this point? All right, I'll just look for a show of hands or someone to speak now on Zoom and hearing none. Thank you, sir. You're excused.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And, sir, can you tell the court, are you from Atlanta?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: No, I grew up in south central Los Angeles. I spent most of my legal career, I would say, in Washington, D.C., was kind of the circle. But I've tried cases all over the country, and I tried the longest. I was the first lawyer to try an international criminal court. I was with the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. I was in trial there for four and a half years in Russia, Tanzania, and Hague and the Netherlands.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK. And when you weren't there, it sounds like your kind of center of gravity Washington, D.C.

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Correct. But I've tried cases in West Virginia and Virginia, Maryland, Florida, I mean, California.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: All over. FLOYD

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And do you, sir, can you tell the court, do you have any children?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: I have one daughter, Fani Willis.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK. And I want to direct your attention back to 2019, OK?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Back in 2019, can you tell the court, did you move here to Atlanta?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: I was living in Johannesburg, South Africa. And unfortunately, for some reasons, I could not get an extended visa. When I retired from the practice of law in 2018, I moved to South Africa, and I had to leave South Africa, and I did then come to Atlanta.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK. And do you, sir, remember about the time period in 2019 when you moved in with your daughter here in Atlanta?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: It would have been the spring or summer of 2019.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And after you moved here, did you get a driver's license to kind of confirm your residency with Atlanta?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, my driver's license for the District of Columbia was going to expire on my birthday, which is in October. And, yes, I did get a license here in the state of Georgia.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Your honor, may I approach the witness?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: You can just take a look at what's been marked --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Whatever you need.

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Yes, I see it was issued on 9/28/2019.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK. So before we get there, do you recognize states exhibit two?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's my driver's license.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And is states exhibit two, a fair and accurate copy of your physical driver's license?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. ABBATE

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: No objection.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Seeing no other objections, states exhibit two is admitted for the record.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Now, and for the record, your honor, the state is going to supplement states exhibit two with a redacted copy of the license. The current copy is not redacted with the address and things of that nature.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. And do we need to mark that differently in any way?

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: I will mark it as states exhibit 2A.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Perfect.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Now, you talked about when your driver's license was issued. Can you tell the court when was that driver's license here, your Georgia driver's license issued?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: It was on 9/28/2019.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK, so September 28, 2019. Now, when you moved into District Attorney Willis's home, who lived there?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Well, my daughter lived there. I lived there. And from time to time, my grandchildren would come.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK. And did your grandchildren, were they at school coming and going?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Exactly. I think they were in school in various jurisdictions.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And during the time, how long did you live at or with Ms. Willis at her home here in Fulton County?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: She was forced to move after she was elected about. I mean, I don't know if you want me to go through the whole thing, but your honor will indulge me. After she was sworn in, she was sworn in on January 1 of 2021. And on or about the 3rd February, at probably 5

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Sorry. Pause there. Mr. Abbate, here's the objection to you.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: I would say it's effect on listener. He was present while all of these things were occurring, but I can.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: No, no, he's saying he was personally present to hear these things.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Yes. MCAFEE

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: OK. And fortunately, the neighbors called the police and disbanded, you know, disbanded the group, and, you know, it was just -- I mean it was just -- I hadn't seen anything exactly like it before.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK. And after that happened, can you tell the court, did Ms. Willis have to move from her home?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Yes, she was forced to leave.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: OK. And can you tell the court after she was forced to leave, shortly after she was sworn in, did you remain at her home in Fulton County?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I stayed there really until 2022, I guess.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And from what you described, did you fear for her safety?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. I mean not only did I do that I mean the South Fulton Police, they had -- they brought somebody, a man with a dog, because there have been so many death threats, and they said they were going to blow up the house, they were going to kill her, they were going to kill me, they were going to kill my grandchildren. I mean, on and on and on. It just -- it became, and I was concerned for her safety.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And after those concerns came to your attention and after what you heard and saw that day, you remained at the house?

utterances.speaker: FLOYD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: And can you tell the court with what you just described, why did you remain living at the district attorney's home here in Fulton County?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I'm sorry. It just -- I see it's irrelevant.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Abbate?

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: I believe it's relevant based on a lot of the questions that were asked yesterday of Ms. Willis as to -- about the security threat and the fact that it was implied that those threats were not necessarily real in the sense that Mr. Floyd remained in the home. There were many questions about the fact that he remained and her children could still come and go to the house. I think it's relevant based to the testimony that was elicited from defense counsel yesterday.
